newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Korea's 1997 copper demands to rise 10.5 pct.
newsitem.headline: S.Korea's 1997 copper demands to rise 10.5 pct.

text.p: South Korea's copper demands are expected to rise by 10.5 percent to 630,000 tonnes in 1997 from its estimate of 570,000 tonnes this year, due mainly to a capacity increase at local cable makers, officials with LG Metals Corp said on Tuesday.

"We expect South Korea's copper demand will rise to 630,000 tonnes next year due to a capacity increase by local cable makers," said So Keum-young, general manager of metals sales at LG Metals. "LG Cable and Sunjin Metals will increase their production capacity to 230,000 tonnes and 120,000 tonnes, respectively, next year."
LG Cable's current annual capacity is 180,000 tonnes, and Sunjin Metals' is 60,000.
LG Metals, South Korea's largest copper producer, is a unit of LG Group. In 1995, LG Metals's copper output totalled 233,300 tonnes.
South Korea's copper demand is expected to grow by four percent every year until the year 2000 and by two percent after 2000, So said.

Demand from the cable industry in 1997 was expected to rise 9.8 percent to 505,000 tonnes from this year's forecasted 460,000 tonnes, while the brass industry's demand was seen rising 13.6 percent to 125,000 tonnes from 110,000 tonnes, he said.
Next year's domestic consumption was expected to rise to 302,000 tonnes from 291,000, while exports were seen rising 17.6 percent to 328,000 tonnes from 279,000 tonnes, So said.
The official added that copper imports this year were forecast to rise 5.5 percent to 330,000 tonnes from 312,900 tonnes in 1995.
"Chile is believed to be supplying 77 percent of South Korea's total copper imports this year," So said.
